question: Question_01_(f)
sols:
Using the hint, we first integrate \emph{f(x)} and make sure it
integrates to 1. Keep in mind that $f(x) = 0$ if $x \not\in [-1,1]$:

\begin{align*} 
1 &= \int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_{-1}^1 f(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_{-1}^1 (Ax+Bx^2)\,dx \\
&= \left. A\frac{x^2}2 + B\frac{x^3}3\right|_{-1}^1 \\
&= B \frac23.\end{align*}

Note that it is no surprise that \emph{A} cancels here, because the term
\emph{Ax} is odd an thus cancels when integrating from \emph{-1} to
\emph{1}.

The calculation above tells us that \textbf{\emph{B} = 3/2}.

The constant \emph{A} needs to ensure that $f(x) \geq 0$, for all
\emph{x}. For very small (in absolute value) negative numbers \emph{x},
the linear term \emph{Ax} dominates the quadratic term \emph{3/2
x\textsuperscript{2}}, so we suspect that \emph{A = 0} is the only
option to keep \emph{f(x)} positive. But let's do the math:

To show that \emph{f(x)} is positive it suffices to show that
\emph{f(x)} is positive at the global minimum of $f(x)$. By the extreme
value theorem, this global minimum will occur at either a critical
point, or at the endpoints of the interval. We can find a critical point
(convince yourself it is a local minimum) by setting \emph{f'(x)} to
zero:

\begin{align*}\displaystyle f'(x) = A+2(3/2)x = A + 3x=0.\end{align*}

Hence \emph{x = -A/3} is the local minimum of \emph{f(x)}. At this point
the value of \emph{f} is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle f(-A/3) = A(-A/3) + 3/2 (-A/3)^2 = -A^2/3 + A^2/6= -A^2/6 \leq 0\end{align*}

for any \emph{A}. Since we need all points, including this critical
point, to satisfy $f(x)\geq{}0$ then we demand \textbf{A=0}. With this
choice of \emph{A}, notice that \emph{$f$(-1)=$f$(1)=3/2\textgreater{}0} so
we have that the local minimum is the global minimum and therefore that
$f(x)\geq{0}$ for all \emph{x}.

\textbf{Final answer: iii.}
hints:
Recall that a probability density function \emph{f(x)} has to satisfy
two conditions:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx = 1,$
\item
  $f(x) \geq 0$, for all \emph{x}.
\end{itemize}
